top_comment.text:
It will definitely be worth the money when its lost half its value and the 
previous owner barely drove the car. Also, the Boxster drives better than 
the Cayman. But these are really the same car, it's only Porsche marketing 
that tries to get everyone to think they are different cars. They're no 
more different cars than a 911 Cabriolet is different than a 911 tin top, 
both are still Carreras using the same parts bin. For marketing reasons 
Porsche decided to sell them to the public as different cars. And 
ironically, the Boxster handles better than the Cayman (and 911) because it 
has a lower center of gravity, it simply does not need the extra rigidity 
of the Cayman if it comes at the cost of more weight up top (where you 
least want it) and has mid engine handling on a short wheelbase. Which is 
precisely why Porsche give the Cayman 10 more horsepower than the Boxster, 
to reduce the advantage of the Boxster's lower center of gravity. Basically 
if you had the same engine in a Boxster, Cayman and 911, the Boxster would 
be the quickest in the hands of 99.9% of drivers. And if they ever add rear 
wheel steering to the Boxster, like on the new GT3, it will be no contest 
win for the Boxster. But Porsche would never do this because as most 
suspect, it costs more to make a Boxster than a base 911, so the profit 
margin is probably much better with the 911.﻿
top_comment.author: porscheoscar

comments.text:
+porscheoscar I don't see how attempting to change the laws of physics is a 
wise strategy. The Boxter is not as rigid because it lacks a proper roof. 
Period end of story. You can't circumvent that fact, no matter how many 
magazines you read.
comments.author: Matty mo (Bjjace1)

comments.text: +itaciar we said.
comments.author: Matty mo (Bjjace1)

comments.text:
+itaciar if you read this maybe you'll know something about this topic.
Or maybe you can tell J. Overbeek he wasn't driving the cars the right way. 
.


http://www.excellence-mag.com/issues/196/articles/open-and-shut-case-track-test#.VAttI4HD_qA
comments.author: porscheoscar

comments.text: here it goes again...
comments.author: itaciar

comments.text:
+Shift4g whenever I see the Cayman GTS being compared to a 911 variant or 
some other car I can't help but be puzzled. The Boxster GTS is the best 
handling mid engine Porsche using a conventional motor. People seem quick 
to forget that the Boxster is not a convertible like the 911 Cab or 
Stingray Convertible, it's a roadster with rigidity already baked into its 
lower COG advantage. The 911 Cab is a compromised 911. The Cayman is a 
compromised Boxster. Each spawned a variant merely to meet a sales demand 
for those who do not like top down cars like Boxster or for those who 
always ask "does it come in a convertible" but are too image conscious to 
be be in anything but the flagship Porsche.
comments.author: porscheoscar

comments.text:
+porscheoscar Which is interesting since many a reviewer have said the 
Cayman formula almost makes the 911 obsolete. Apparently the Boxster is 
better than both.
comments.author: Shift4g

comments.text:
+itaciar Excellence is the Porsche magazine most commonly read by actual 
Porsche owners. And Chris Harris, unlike J. Overbeek, is not a professional 
race car driver. Weigh their opinions accordingly. Or ignore their opinions 
completely and simply look at the time sheets, the Boxster Spyder was 
quicker than the Cayman R on every single lap during that shoot out. And 
the margin between the Boxster and Cayman, given the twisty venue, was 
substantially in the Boxster's favor. A "fucking convertible" as you put 
it, tends to have a lower center of gravity. Perhaps you should think about 
getting your own Excellence subscription guy. You don't seem to know what 
you're talking about.
comments.author: porscheoscar

comments.text:
+porscheoscar i don't know which magazines you have read, but the magazines 
and the reviews by reliable test drivers like Chris Harris and other big 
names, which I and others have read and seen, would say exactly the 
opposite. I can tell you that aside from yourself, no one else would agree 
Boxster has any advantage over the Cayman, except for the open top. Cayman 
is overall a more focused driver's car with superb weight distribution; on 
the other hand, Boxster is a fucking convertible. You should stop reading 
that magazine called "excellence". it should be call "misguiding magazine".
comments.author: itaciar

comments.text:
+jojo0827 it still applies because the Boxster's core advantage is still 
the same: lower center of gravity, even if the cars weigh the same (and now 
with a wider front end -- double win). Which is why Porsche has to give the 
Cayman a slight power bump, but not too much so it doesn't inch too close 
to the base 991 Carrera. There has been this long held belief that the 
Cayman "feels" like the driver's car. But you can't win an argument with 
center of gravity unless there's a substantial weight or power difference, 
neither of which is the case here. Porsche slipped up and made a Boxster 
that was on the level of the Cayman R with the Boxster Spyder. I seriously 
doubt that will happen again. We'll see a Cayman GT4 for sure but a Boxster 
GT4? Don't think so, this would make it the Porsche that checks the boxes: 
light, short wheel base, lowest COG with the most neutral handling. Check 
x4. That would throw a wrench in Porsche's marketing plan of positioning 
the Cayman on performance as the car between the Boxster and Carrera. *On 
equal power* the Boxster would be the quickest and best handling of all of 
Porsche's cars. Just like the 550 Spyder was back in the 1950's and early 
1960's. A car they even fitted with a Formula One engine, but that was a 
different Porsche company than the marketing machine of today.
comments.author: porscheoscar

comments.text:
+porscheoscar I'm not too sure that applies to the current gen of models. 
Most all reviews I've read say the Cayman feels like the better driver's 
car, since the fixed roof gives a sharper, stiffer chassis.
comments.author: jojo0827

comments.text:
Not an opinion. To compare handling, Excellence magazine tested this with a 
Cayman R and Boxster Spyder on a karting track using a well known 
professional Porsche driver. The Boxster was both: quicker on every lap and 
according to Van Overbeek, was easier to drive at the limit.

comments.text:
Not sure why you think Porsche should be affordable by everyone, they are a 
luxury item, but don't worry, nearly every car they sell depreciates about 
50% in 7-8 years, and then continues to drop over the next 5 years until it 
is about 25% of the original cost. Then in about 40-50 years people will 
suddenly think it's the most amazing thing ever, and the market will 
suddenly spike and in 18 months they'll be worth about 100x more than they 
cost new. Unless it's a FR Porsche, they'll always be cheap because no one 
wants those pieces of junk for anything other than thrashing around race 
tracks for cheap. So the trick is just to buy them at the right time, and 
you don't really lose $ on the sale price if you end up not keeping the car 
for too long. One pro of the modern cars is they are actually pretty 
reliable and can be driven regularly, but you can still expect to pay 
$6k-10k a year in scheduled upkeep (tires at least once a year, maybe more 
often depending on driving, oil changes, brakes, etc.), unless there is a 
major unscheduled repair and you are stuck with a $15k-20k repair bill for 
something like engine/transmission. My point being that the cost of the car 
isn't even really the big expense of ownership. Just owning and maintaining 
a Porsche can be expensive and end up costing more than the purchase did!
comments.author: joeracer302

comments.text:
Good point Jeff...I think all of the top manufacturers could have one 
stripped down old-school entry-level machine which gets the basics right 
and is super-fun to drive. A car that pay's homage to the '60s and '70s 
sports cars, but benefitting from what's been learned in the meantime and 
modern materials and construction techniques. Such a car might take it's 
inspiration from Lotus Elan or Mazda MX-5...small...super lightweight...but 
add the excitement of some good horsepower and at least a 6 cylinder N/A 
engine. Imagine what Ferrari could come up with if they put their minds to 
that recipe?...Something like a cooler and sexier looking Elise but with a 
6 cylinder high-revving engine?

version: Cayman with the 991S X51 engine (430bhp) .... That makes sense

comments.text:
+Photoandcargeek addendum, when I meant pushing the 911 to it's limit I 
meant the 991S because arguably the Turbo/GT3/GT2 are faster versions but 
the turbo is more of a GT and it is 4 wheel drive, GT2 and 3 are race cars 
for the road which I could live with but most people including my wife 
can't! Hence, I see the 991S as what should be the competitor of the F458 
which clearly isn't the case.... My stock 996 Jahre is faster than a 
regular F355 on a track.
comments.author: Photoandcargeek

comments.text:
+Jared Caputo OK so in terms of performance it males no sense ... But, what 
they do is push a bunch of options that you don't really want and which are 
charged to you at barely less than full price. I don't know about now but, 
in a not so distant past, my dealership was all over me to try and sell me 
the latest model and told me that I could get the options at discounted 
prices. Even if discounts don't exist anymore, I don't feel highly about 
push marketing. On top of that, when the consumers will start being annoyed 
by Porsche's strategy, it will start hurting the brand and that will take 
years and money to be forgotten ... 
Lastly, although I have owned a GT3 that I have downgraded for a 996 40 
jahre edition (which I bought 7 years ago for the price of a non 
anniversary car), I see the difference between a 991 and my car, the inside 
is much nicer, the car probably corners faster on a track but, in every day 
use mine is more raw and feels every bit as fast in a staight line ... 
There is not enough of a difference to my taste for me to "upgrade". During 
the same period of time, Ferrari had moved on from the F355 (which is drop 
dead gorgeous but close to 996 fast) to the 458 which is a beast of a car. 
It seems quite obvious to me that Porsche will soon come out with a F458 
rival using the 918 chassis or the Huracan/R8 next generation chassis but 
will be in a few years time and will be a totally new product line instead 
of pushing the 911 or the Cayman to it's maximum potential.
comments.author: Photoandcargeek

comments.text:
Well, in addition to the horsepower, you also get the sport exhaust, 
no-cost full leather interior, the additional styling and aerodynamic 
elements, PASM, Sport Chrono, larger rims and more. Now (as with the 
Panamera 4S vs GTS), if you add all these on to the "S" car, it ends up 
being more expensive than the GTS (and the GTS gives you the styling and 
the additional power as well). So, in my opinion, the GTS is more of a 
"deal" if you're going to get those options anyway -- and if you are 
getting those options anyway, you want a Gran Turismo Sport.

It makes sense if you think of it that way -- it's a car that bundles all 
the sport features, adds horsepower and design enhancements, larger rims, 
and a full leather or Alcantera interior for less than it would be on the 
Cayman S if configured that way (and some features can't be configured on a 
Cayman S).

Also -- Cayman GT4 expected soon: 
http://blog.caranddriver.com/someone-call-911-and-tell-it-a-porsche-cayman-gt4-model-is-coming-for-it/
comments.author: Jared Caputo

+Mykell Schexnayder 6, 7, 8 figures? Dang... My dad's a doctor and some of 
his colleagues finance a Porsche 911 or Cayenne while supporting a family 
with $370,000 a year. You don't need to be Bill Gates or a mob boss to own 
a Porsche!

Plus, if you find a new Porsche on the lot, they might come well equipped 
so you won't notice the price of those little bits and pieces. All you'll 
notice is the final MSRP that the dealer gives. 
I do agree that some Porsche models are overpriced but you can easily find 
a Porsche Boxster S for $70,000 or a base 911 for $98,000 or so. They won't 
be as lavishly equipped as a BMW M4 or Mercedes AMG for the same money, but 
a Porsche is still great.
Have a good job, get a good down payment on it coupled with a great credit 
score (and a small family or no family at all) and you don't have to be so 
concerned.

was totally impressed. Acceleration, engine sound, handling, comfort, so 
much of a joy, and even though boxster was more expensive I chosen boxster. 
And that was comparison between nissan350z 300hp and boxster base 2.7 
240hp, and this here is new boxster gts with over 300hp, man you cannot 
even compare old nissan 350z to those beasts.

captions.text: Was that thunder?
That sharpens everything up and away you go...

Today is a very good day. I'm driving a Porsche
Boxster, roof down, good weather, on a mountain

road in Mallorca. It doesn't really get much
better than this, you know.

However, before any customer gets to experience
this, they have to go through the painful

procedure of specifying up their perfect car.
And as with any Porsche, that's a tricky and

costly business. And now, that decision is
even more difficult for Boxster S and Cayman

S buyers, thanks to the launch of the new
GTS models.

They cost around £6,000 more and come with
some unique front and rear bumpers, plus a

15bhp upgrade to their 3.4-litre engines,
which means the Boxster now has 330bhp and
the Cayman 340bhp.

The GTS models also feature a feast of extra
kit, which you may or may not want to fit

to your S anyway. And so today, I'm going
to try and find out the if the added value

of the GTS makes it a no-brainer to upgrade
over the S.

For instance, you get the Porsche sports exhaust
as standard and that'll normally cost you

£1,530 and you definitely want that, because
its changes the sound of the flat-six engine

from this, which is pretty nice, to this when
I press the button -

I think that's nicer and it even makes this
noise when you kick it down a gear.

Was that thunder? I definitely don't see rain
clouds...

The 
GTS also has alcantara and leather trim on
the dash. If you want hide on the dash of

your S model, which you do if you want the
car to feel as posh as it should, you'll need
extended leather and that's a £1,740 option.

So, already, if you were buying a Boxster
S, you'd have spent over £3,000 on extras
anyway.

However, things are about to get a little
bit confusing because the GTS comes with some

items you wouldn't necessarily want, such
as smoked rear-light clusters - £320. I wouldn't

bother with those. Then there's the Sports
Seat Plus, £546 for those. They are nice,

but they're not really necessary. £447 for
direction headlamp beams. You've got to be

kidding, right? There's no way I'm buying
those.

£971 to go from the 19-inch to 20-inch alloy
wheels and they do look nice, don't they?

But you're going to end up kerbing those.
When you add all those options up, they come

to pretty much the same price as the satellite
navigation system and frankly, I'd rather
have that as it'll be more useful every day.

All what I've just said about the Boxster
applies equally to the Cayman. But there are

some other extras I've not yet mentioned which
equally affect the handling and after all,
that is what this coupe version is all about.

The GTS also gets Porsche Active Suspension
Management as standard and normally, that

would cost you £971 and it's an option you
definitely want because it lowers the car

by 10mm for improved responses. Because you've
got adapted dampers, when you're just cruising

along with it in normal mode, it's nice and
comfy.

And then when you press this button down here,
it sharpens everything up and away you go.

If you regularly take your car on a circuit,
instead of the active suspension, you can

have the sports chassis which lowers the car
by a further 10mm but has fixed rate dampers.

It's great for Track Day junkies and if your
name is Walter Röhrl, but forget it if you
mainly drive on the road.

Last but not least, there's the Sports Chrono
package. Now, that would normally cost you

£1,085 and as part of it, you get active
engine mounts and what they do, is hold the

engine firmly in place when you're braking,
accelerating or cornering, and that apparently

improves the car's balance, but I think I
can live without that. I'm not entirely sure

I'm going to be able to discern that when
I'm out driving out on the road.

I'd rather Porsche fitted the car with the
£890 torque vectoring to improve the amount

of grip you have. Sports Chrono also includes
a stopwatch on the dash, which you don't really

need. There's also a slightly sharper throttle
response and a more lenient stability control

system - both of which I think are items you
won't miss either.

Cars with PDK gearboxes also get launch control
and that enables the Cayman to sprint from

0-62mph in just 4.6 seconds. To activate it
it's dead easy - you just put the car in drive,

put it in Sports Plus mode, put your left
foot on the brake, mash the throttle and when

it says launch control, you then release the
brake and away you go.

The thing is, the only time I ever use launch
control is to give a demonstration to you

guys. In every day driving, I've never used
it once so it's pointless. That brings us

back to whether the GTS is worth a £6,000
premium over the S.

Well, seeing as you'd only need to spend £4,000
to get the right optional equipment, you're

effectively paying £2,000 extra for a GTS
badge, some unique bumpers and an extra 15bhp.

Do you know what? I'd be lying if I told you
I could feel the extra 15bhp out here on the

road. I'd also be lying if I told you I really
cared the GTS badge had a bit of history attached

to it. For me, I'd rather take that £2,000
and spend it on the excellent PDK paddleshift

automatic gearbox. And so for me, the GTS
isn't really worth it. I'd be better off getting

a normal Cayman or Boxster S, and speccing
it up exactly as I want it.

However, that's just my opinion. People who
want to be able to say they own the ultimate

Boxster or Cayman won't have any trouble in
justifying the extra cash for the GTS.

So, I suppose the final question is, is should
you go for the Boxster or the Cayman? Quite

frankly, that comes down to whether you want
a coupe or a convertible and personally for

me after having driven both cars back-to-back
on these fabulous roads, I got a little bit

more out of being able to take the roof down,
than the sharper dynamics you get from having
the roof fixed.

In this particular instance, I'm going to
take the Boxster.

Click on the video windows to watch our in-depth
of the Porsche Boxster and the Cayman track-battle.

Click on the play icon to watch our very latest
video review and on the Auto Express logo
to subscribe to our YouTube channel.

title: Porsche Cayman GTS and Boxster GTS review - are they worth it?
